title: 109_s56
content:
The Act titled "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area and defines key terms such as Commission and Secretary. Establishment of Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado to conserve natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources along the Rio Grande River. Boundaries extend from Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge to New Mexico State border. Secretary to prepare map and legal description for public inspection. Commission establishment. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various organizations and the general public. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, representing various organizations and the general public. Members serve 5-year terms without compensation, elect a chairperson, and hold quarterly public meetings. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission meets quarterly, with public meetings that are open to the public. The Commission receives technical assistance from the Secretary and other Federal agencies as needed. The Commission has powers as outlined in Section 5. The Commission may hold hearings, enter into cooperative agreements for managing non-Federal land, prohibit acquisition of real property, and implement management plans. The Commission is prohibited from acquiring real property or interests in real property. They are required to assist the Secretary in implementing the management plan to preserve and interpret natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources of the Natural Area. They may also assist the State of Colorado in preserving state land and wildlife, increasing public awareness, and encouraging political subdivisions of the state. The curr_chunk focuses on increasing public awareness and appreciation for the natural resources in the Natural Area, encouraging land use policies consistent with the management plan, and assisting private landowners in implementing the plan. The Secretary and the Commission, along with other agencies and landowners, must prepare management plans for the Natural Area within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will handle Federal land management, while the Commission will manage non-Federal land and submit their plan for approval. The Commission must notify the Secretary of reasons for disapproval and allow for revisions to the management plan. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land. The management plans should consider existing Federal, State, and local plans for preservation, restoration, and conservation. Plans for Federal land in the Natural Area must comply with relevant laws and be in line with adjacent land management plans. An inventory of Natural Area resources must be included in the management plans. The management plan for the Natural Area should be considered an amendment to the San Luis Resource Management Plan and include an inventory of resources, recommendations for resource management policies, and publication in the Federal Register. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION OF NATURAL AREA. The Secretary shall administer the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws and the management plan, ensuring conservation, protection of resources, limited public recreation, wildlife habitat protection, prohibition on water storage facilities, and reduction in roads and motorized vehicles. The management plan for the Natural Area includes reducing roads and motorized vehicles, negotiating streamflow changes with stakeholders, applying the plan to private land with owner consent, and withdrawing Federal land from certain activities. The management plan for the Natural Area includes reducing roads and motorized vehicles, negotiating streamflow changes with stakeholders, applying the plan to private land with owner consent, and withdrawing Federal land from certain activities. The Secretary may acquire land in the Natural Area from willing sellers and administer it according to the management plan and this Act. Section 5(d)(1) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act does not apply to the Natural Area. SEC. 8. EFFECT.

This Act does not conflict with the Rio Grande Compact, regulate private land in the Natural Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create Federal water rights, impose stricter water quality standards, or prevent Colorado from acquiring instream flow rights. 

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Funding is authorized to carry out this Act.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION.

The Commission will end 10 years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriations are authorized to carry out this Act.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION.

The Commission will terminate 10 years after the Act's enactment.
